Situation1: They openly turn to each other for help in a difficult personal moment.
Situation2: They actively help a mentee navigate a challenging project with regular check-ins and feedback.
Story: My phone buzzed with a message from my younger sister: “Can we talk? I really need you.” She never reached out unless it was serious. I glanced at the clock—ten minutes until my scheduled video call with Maya, my mentee, who was struggling to keep her project on track. She’d been waiting all week for this feedback session, and I knew how much she depended on my guidance. But my sister’s text tugged at me; we’d always promised to be there for each other, no matter what. I could picture her sitting alone, hoping I’d pick up, just as I’d done for her so many times before. My mind raced, torn between the responsibility to support my family and the commitment I’d made to Maya. Both needed me, both counted on me, and I felt the weight of their expectations pressing in from both sides. My heart pounded as I stared at my phone, caught between the brother my sister needed and the mentor Maya deserved.
